Situation1: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story:
The radar screen glows with a web of circling aircraft, each blip a responsibility pressing on my shoulders. A major route closure has just been announced, and now dozens of flights are stacking up, waiting for my instructions. My headset crackles with pilots’ voices, tense and expectant, relying on me to keep them safe and the airspace flowing. I know every second counts; a single misstep could mean chaos in the sky.

My phone buzzes on the desk, a message from Maya: “We’re live now. More people needed. Can you come?” I glance at the stream—my friends, holding signs, their voices echoing for justice. I promised I’d be there, that I’d help amplify our cause. They’re counting on me to show up, to stand with them, to be more than just a voice online.

But here, in this tower, I am the only thing standing between order and disaster. My heart pounds as I weigh the urgency of the skies against the urgency of the streets, feeling the impossible pull of both worlds demanding all of me, right now.
